text: The Elephant and the Jackal

1 The Elephant and the Jackal

ROAD MAP

The Elephant and
the Jackal

P2-3 Reading and comprehension
(Guided practice)

P4 Vocabulary and Pronunciation

P5 Grammar

P11 Aptitude Track (Independent practice)

LEARNING OUTCOMES

Through the course of the lesson
1. Students gain
• vocabulary skills
• communication skills
• reading and writing skills
• comprehension skills

2. Students learn
• new words and their usage
• ethics and values

3. Students discover
• their feelings for the characters and
their circumstances
• that doing wrong to someone invites the
same fate for oneself
• the golden rule that ‘do unto others as you
would have them do unto you’

4. Students develop
• observation skills
• logical reasoning skills
• storytelling skills

GEAR UP

Cognitive Development
Development of Literacy
Cultural and Aesthetic Development

Initiative and self-direction
Creative thinking
Critical thinking

1. Colour the given picture of an elephant and her calf.

2. Now answer the following questions.
a. Elephants have big __________ (eyes/ears/tail/nose).
b. Elephants have a tiny __________ (tail/nose/legs/eyes).
c. What is a group of elephants called? __________ (a flock/a herd/a school/a group)
d. An elephant’s trunk is similar in function to which human body part? __________ (nose/mouth/foot/stomach)
e. What is an elephant’s favourite treat? __________ (meat/sugarcane/bones/candy)
f. Elephants are __________ (black/brown/grey/red) in colour.

Once upon a time, there lived an elephant named Karpurathilaka in a dense
forest. He was a big troublemaker. He would disturb other animals, shake the
trees, and rip the branches for no reason. Due to this, many nests which had
eggs were destroyed. All the birds and animals, including strong animals like
tiger and lion, were worried and did not trouble him. Everyone wanted to get
rid of him.

One day, as usual, Karpurathilaka destroyed the burrows of the jackals. This
angered the jackals who decided to take revenge on the elephant.

This is too much. We must teach this beast a lesson.
But how? It is not easy to beat a huge elephant like him!

At that time, an old jackal stood up.

Check-in
Why would the elephant shake the trees and rip the branches?
................................................
a. for fun
b. for revenge
c. for no reason
d. to make more space

Rhyming words
take cake
stood wood

Leave this problem to me.
I will teach him a good lesson.

Everyone was happy and agreed with the old jackal. The next morning, the old jackal set out for his mission. The old jackal went near Karpurathilaka and kneeled down in front of him.

My lord! Please look at me.

Who are you? And why have you come to me?

Rhyming words

down town
such much

My lord, I am a poor jackal. You are the largest and bravest in the
forest. You are also very kind-hearted and gentle towards other
animals. The animals have decided to make you the king of the forest.
I am here as a messenger and request you to accept the offer.

The elephant was very happy to hear such good words about him.

Check-in
Who was the largest and
bravest in the forest?
.........................................
a. the elephant
b. the old jackal
c. a monkey
d. a lion

My lord, the animals are waiting to see your kingship ceremony. It will be held at the centre of the forest. It is the most auspicious place to take charge as king.

The foolish elephant believed the jackal at once and agreed to accompany him to the ceremony. Both the jackal and the elephant started to move deep into the forest. On their way, they had to cross a swampy area. The jackal could Walk easily across the swampy area, but the elephant could not. As soon as he placed his feet in the muddy area, he got stuck and started sinking. He tried his best to come out but could not.

My dear friend, please help me to come out of this place. I am sinking!

Rhyming words

deep seep
walk talk

You cruel beast, now do you realize how it feels to be troubled by others? You killed so many eggs and babies of other animals. You spoiled our burrows and the nests of so many birds. You very well deserved this punishment.

The elephant felt sorry and promised the jackal never to trouble others again.

Check-in
Who did the elephant kill?
................................................
a. babies of other animals
b. humans
c. other animals
d. insects

The story takes place _________
(in a forest/in a tree/on a farm/near the sea).

b. Why did the animals want to get rid of the elephant?
The animals wanted to get rid of the elephant because _________
(he was too big/he was lazy/he troubled others).

c. Why did the elephant accompany the jackal?

(he wanted to be king/he wanted to be friends with the jackal/he wanted to
live with the jackal/he wanted to trouble others).

d. What happened on the way?
The elephant _________
(lost the way/changed his mind/turned back/got stuck in the mud).

e. Do you think the old jackal helped Karpurathilaka after he felt sorry for his
actions? Discuss.

VOCABULARY aNd PRONUNCIATION
(animal sounds)
Did you know that animals make sounds to communicate?
‘Meow! meow!’ says the cat, when she/he is hungry.
Similarly, other animals also make sounds.

1. Match the name of the animal with the sound it makes.

a. cow (1) neigh! neigh!
b. horse (2) chirp! chirp!
c. bird (3) moo! moo!
d. crow (4) hiss! hiss!
e. snake (5) croak! croak!
f. frog (6) caw! caw!

(synonyms)
Synonyms are words that have the same or nearly the same meaning.
Examples: small—tiny big—huge

2. Find the synonyms for the underlined words.
clean large glad tiny less

a. I have very little food in my lunch box.
I have very __________ food in my lunch box.
b. A newborn baby has small toes and fingers.
A newborn baby has __________ toes and fingers.
c. An elephant is a big animal.
An elephant is a __________ animal.
d. We should keep our classroom tidy.
We should keep our classroom __________.
e. Hari was pleased to meet his old friend.
Hari was to meet his old friend.

(‘sh’ sound words)
Listen to your teacher read the following words and repeat after your teacher.
she shape shirt shore
sheet shark shoe shadow
shell sheep short shoulder
shelf ship shower shock

3. Complete the ‘sh’ words from the clues given above.
a. Found on the seashore: s h
b. Pairs with socks: s h
c. Pairs with pants: s h
d. Water transport: s h

GRAMMAR
Cognitive Development
Development of Literacy

Critical thinking
Communication
Initiative and self-direction

(nouns—revision)
In your previous class, you had learnt that a noun is a name of a person, place, or
thing.
Examples:
1. Vinu is sick.
‘Vinu’ is a noun since it is the name of a person.
2. My grandmother is going to the hospital.
‘Hospital’ is a noun since it is the name of a place.
3. I lost my pencil.
‘Pencil’ is a noun since it is the name of a thing.

1. Read aloud and underline the nouns in the given passage.
Shalu and her friends Rani, Deepa, and Yogesh are in a garden. The garden has
many flowers such as white lilies, yellow sunflowers, and red roses. There are
also some jasmines and marigolds. The garden has many big trees. It has few
benches for people to sit. Rani is thrilled to see many butterflies. The garden has
a big pond. The ducks are swimming in the pond with their ducklings. Inside
the pond, we can see some fish swimming.

(proper and common nouns)
There are different types of nouns such as proper nouns and common nouns.
Proper nouns are names of persons, places, or things.
They give us the actual name of the person, place, or thing.
Examples: Ravi, Lakshmi, Delhi, Chennai

Remember: Proper nouns begin with a capital letter.

A common noun can name anyone in a group of persons, places, or things.
Examples: boy, girl, log, city
Some more examples of proper and common nouns are given below.
1. Rekha is a kind lady.
Rekha—proper noun
lady—common noun
2. Diya played with her sister.
Diya—proper noun
sister—common noun
3. Peter has a pet cat.
Peter—proper noun
cat—common noun

2. Read the sentences. If the noun is common, write ‘common noun’ on the
given line. If the noun is proper, rewrite the noun on the given line using
capital letters.
Example: woman—common noun
assam—Assam
a. month __________ b. park __________
c. village __________ d. flower __________
e. ganesh __________ f. rita __________
g. sheeba __________ h. box __________
i. jaipur __________ j. hotel __________
k. river __________ l. street __________
m. cat __________ n. table __________

(listening to a letter)
1. Listen to your teacher read a letter. The letter is written by Arun, about his
house, to his friend Ajit, who lives in Chennai. Write the missing words
correctly.
From
Arun
Bannerghatta Road,
Bengaluru
To
Ajit
Anna Nagar,
Chennai
Dear Ajit,
How are you? I received your mail and I am very __________ for this
late reply.
I shifted my house and I am very __________ about it.
At the same time, I feel __________ that I have to leave all my friends
in the old place and move to a new area.
Our new __________ is a small bungalow with a __________
garden in the front.
It has six rooms. I have my own bedroom.
Oscar, my pet dog, __________ in my room. He likes my room the best.
I keep my room very neat and __________.
During your next vacation, please try and make a visit to my
__________ house.
Yours lovingly,
Arun

(role-play—picture description about rooms)
Have you noticed the different types of rooms in your home?
They are the drawing room/living room, bedroom, dining room, kitchen, and
bathroom.

2. Read aloud with your partner the following conversation between friends
about what they do in each room of their house.

a. Rahul: Which room do you sit in
to have your dinner?
Sonu: I sit in the dining room to
have my dinner.

b. Minu: Do you know what happens
in the kitchen?
Tina: Yes, I do. My mother and
father cook food in the kitchen.
They also wash the dishes in the
sink.

c. Gopi: Which room do you sleep in
at night?
Hari: I sleep in my bedroom.

d. Tim: I take bath in my bathroom.
John: I also brush my teeth in my
bathroom.
